drug.name: Aprindine
drug.description: Aprindine is a cardiac depressant used in arrhythmias.
drug.synthesis-reference: Vanhoof, P. and Clarebout, P.; British Patent 1,321,424; June 27, 1973; assigned to Manufac- ture de Produits Pharmaceutiques A. Christiaens, SA

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of organic compounds known as indanes. These are compounds containing an indane moiety, which consists of a cyclopentane fused to a benzene ring.

property.source: Vanhoof, P. and Clarebout, P.; British Patent 1,321,424; June 27, 1973; assigned to Manufacture de Produits Pharmaceutiques A. Christiaens, SA

target.name: Sodium channel protein type 5 subunit alpha

article.citation: Sato R, Hisatome I, Tanaka Y, Sasaki N, Kotake H, Mashiba H, Katori R: Aprindine blocks the sodium current in guinea-pig ventricular myocytes. Naunyn Schmiedebergs Arch Pharmacol. 1991 Sep;344(3):331-6.
Kamiya K, Kodama I, Toyama J: A combination of inactivated sodium channel blockers causes competitive interaction on dV/dtmax of single ventricular myocytes. Cardiovasc Res. 1991 Jun;25(6):516-22.

polypeptide.name: Sodium channel protein type 5 subunit alpha
polypeptide.general-function: Voltage-gated sodium channel activity involved in sa node cell action potential
polypeptide.specific-function: This protein mediates the voltage-dependent sodium ion permeability of excitable membranes. Assuming opened or closed conformations in response to the voltage difference across the membrane, the protein forms a sodium-selective channel through which Na(+) ions may pass in accordance with their electrochemical gradient. It is a tetrodotoxin-resistant Na(+) channel isoform. This channel is responsible for the initial upstroke of the action potential. Channel inactivation is regulated by intracellular calcium levels.

synonyms.synonym: Sodium channel protein cardiac muscle subunit alpha
Sodium channel protein type V subunit alpha
Voltage-gated sodium channel subunit alpha Nav1.5

article.citation: Levine SN, Hollier B: Aprindine inhibits calmodulin-stimulated phosphodiesterase and Ca-ATPase activities. J Cardiovasc Pharmacol. 1983 Jan-Feb;5(1):151-6.

polypeptide.name: Calmodulin
polypeptide.specific-function: Calmodulin mediates the control of a large number of enzymes, ion channels, aquaporins and other proteins by Ca(2+). Among the enzymes to be stimulated by the calmodulin-Ca(2+) complex are a number of protein kinases and phosphatases. Together with CCP110 and centrin, is involved in a genetic pathway that regulates the centrosome cycle and progression through cytokinesis.

polypeptide.name: Cytochrome P450 2D6
polypeptide.specific-function: Responsible for the metabolism of many drugs and environmental chemicals that it oxidizes. It is involved in the metabolism of drugs such as antiarrhythmics, adrenoceptor antagonists, and tricyclic antidepressants.

article.citation: Teirlynck O, Belpaire FM, Andreasen F: Binding of aprindine and moxaprindine to human serum, alpha 1-acid glycoprotein and serum of healthy and diseased humans. Eur J Clin Pharmacol. 1982;21(5):427-31.

polypeptide.name: Alpha-1-acid glycoprotein 1
polypeptide.specific-function: Functions as transport protein in the blood stream. Binds various ligands in the interior of its beta-barrel domain. Also binds synthetic drugs and influences their distribution and availability in the body. Appears to function in modulating the activity of the immune system during the acute-phase reaction.

go-classifier.description: negative regulation of tumor necrosis factor production
